body:
Hi!
Can you provide some details here such as 
1. Version of code (either release version or `git log | head` output if you are running a different version
2.  A sample of your DAG
3. Steps to reproduce
4. Deployment architecture (e.g. single node with both Webserver and Scheduler+LocalExecutor running, Celery installation, etc....?)
5. Any other details
@amerkel2 Unless I hear otherwise by EOD, I will close this issue.
@bolkedebruin could I get a further review/merge?
Oh nice, is this a full implementation of PEP 249 ? If so you should think about sharing it as its own thing on Pypi. In the meantime I'm happy merging it as is.
We get random failures on travis sometimes, I re-triggered it

Can you add a test that hits that endpoint in here?
https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/blob/master/tests/core.py#L725
Agree. Closing.
Agree. This is a good feature to add. Adding the E/HW labels.

I am running the following for the code listed on https://gist.github.com/r39132/b22671d0293cd7740b38 `airflow clear -t foo_1 -s 2016-02-04T00:50:00 test_s3_sensor` The command shows me : ``` You are about to delete these 8 tasks: ``` Which is correct according to the Tree View below : When I choose `yes`, my tree view looks like the picture below with 8 new blank squares appearing in the `foo_1` task only for the dates displayed above: I cannot reproduce your bug and am therefore closing.
Closing for now until I have a more concise definition of the work.
Fixed. Closing.
We run hourly DAGs as well as daily DAGs. XCom work for both. Should you have specific questions, jump on the gitter channel: https://gitter.im/airbnb/airflow
@mistercrunch ya, full impl, but read-only. The inserts are disabled for now. I agree, would be nice to move to its own project (with tests). I'll add to my TODO.

This is pretty much a requirement for me to be able to run a multi-tennant Airflow server.  User's jobs need to run under their own credentials in order to be able to write to their HDFS resources.  Without this the account running the executor needs to own the data for every user's jobs.
ping @mistercrunch
@mistercrunch any idea when this will be released?
Very nice. thanks for the PR.

We're at least 3 weeks away from the next release. I'm out on PTO next week and we have a production code freeze for that reason. Once I get back I'd like to stabilize what's in master now for at least one week in production at Airbnb before the next release. 

Release cycles should get much faster later this quarter when we have our staging environment in place and a more automated process. Bear with us!

In the meantime you can easily run from source, directly on the current master if you feel like a pioneer, or make yourself a version by starting from `airbnb_prod` and cherry picking the commits you need.
@0xR curious, are you using the BQ airflow stuff?
@mistercrunch - I tested your changes locally and it looks good. Thanks!

Very basic patch. Tested that it works. One thing that's annoying is that the logout button shows when not logged in. I tried adding: ``` {% if current_user.is_authenticated %}
  • Logout
    • {% endif %} ``` But it current_user seems totally messed up. When not logged in, current_user is `AnonymousUserMixin`, as expected, but when logged in, it's `None`. Open to suggestions on what to do there.
Looks like I need to add a test to raise code coverage.  I'll investigate...

can we use an icon with a tooltip?

Check out `glyphicon-off`
@kretes Can you share a screen shot of your DAG (graph view)?

Teamwork!
![img](https://media.giphy.com/media/LmpHsHFG1ZoRy/giphy.gif)
Oh backfill includes upstream dependencies related to the tasks that match your regex.
Yeah..that's what I was thinking as well. I was waiting to see the graph before reaching that conclusion:-)

@kretes I suspect your issue is not related to the regex match, but that after the regex match is found for a task, the task's upstream dependencies are being executed, which is what one would expect to happen if those dependencies have not yet completed successfully. Let me illustrate with an example. Also, this is the sort of detail in order to better turn your issues around : A. My DAG Code ``` import os from airflow import DAG from airflow.operators import * from datetime import datetime, timedelta from datetime import date START_DATE = datetime(2016, 2, 4, 0, 0, 0) default_args = { 'owner':'sanand', 'depends_on_past': False, 'start_date': START_DATE, 'email': ['sanand@agari.com'], 'email_on_failure': True, 'email_on_retry': True, 'retries': 0, 'retry_delay': timedelta(minutes=1), } dag = DAG( dag_id='test_regex_1', default_args=default_args, schedule_interval='@hourly', dagrun_timeout=timedelta(minutes=60*5)) dummy_op_1 = DummyOperator( task_id='dummy_1', dag=dag) dummy_op_2 = DummyOperator( task_id='dummy_2', dag=dag) dummy_op_3 = DummyOperator( task_id='bash_sqm_22', dag=dag) dummy_op_3.set_upstream(dummy_op_2) dummy_op_2.set_upstream(dummy_op_1) ``` B. My DAG Visualized C. Reproduce the Issue and expected behavior `airflow backfill -l -t bash_sqm_22 -s 2016-01-15T00:00:00 -e 2016-01-15T01:00:00 test_regex_1` I expect this to execute 2 hourly runs for `bash_sqm_22`, but I also expect `dummy_2` and `dummy_1`to complete. D. Provide a log ``` [2016-02-10 16:45:54,276] {base_executor.py:34} INFO - Adding to queue: airflow run test_regex_1 dummy_1 2016-01-15T01:00:00 --local -s 2016-01-15T00:00:00 -sd DAGS_FOLDER/test_regex.py [2016-02-10 16:45:54,278] {base_executor.py:34} INFO - Adding to queue: airflow run test_regex_1 dummy_1 2016-01-15T00:00:00 --local -s 2016-01-15T00:00:00 -sd DAGS_FOLDER/test_regex.py [2016-02-10 16:45:59,234] {jobs.py:810} INFO - [backfill progress] waiting: 6 | succeeded: 0 | kicked_off: 2 | failed: 0 | wont_run: 0 [2016-02-10 16:45:59,236] {local_executor.py:29} INFO - LocalWorker running airflow run test_regex_1 dummy_1 2016-01-15T00:00:00 --local -s 2016-01-15T00:00:00 -sd DAGS_FOLDER/test_regex.py [2016-02-10 16:45:59,236] {local_executor.py:29} INFO - LocalWorker running airflow run test_regex_1 dummy_1 2016-01-15T01:00:00 --local -s 2016-01-15T00:00:00 -sd DAGS_FOLDER/test_regex.py [2016-02-10 16:45:59,815] {__init__.py:36} INFO - Using executor SequentialExecutor [2016-02-10 16:45:59,815] {__init__.py:36} INFO - Using executor SequentialExecutor Logging into: /Users/siddharth/Projects/airflow/logs/test_regex_1/dummy_1/2016-01-15T00:00:00 Logging into: /Users/siddharth/Projects/airflow/logs/test_regex_1/dummy_1/2016-01-15T01:00:00 [2016-02-10 16:46:00,816] {__init__.py:36} INFO - Using executor SequentialExecutor [2016-02-10 16:46:00,817] {__init__.py:36} INFO - Using executor SequentialExecutor [2016-02-10 16:46:04,237] {jobs.py:810} INFO - [backfill progress] waiting: 6 | succeeded: 0 | kicked_off: 2 | failed: 0 | wont_run: 0 [2016-02-10 16:46:04,255] {base_executor.py:34} INFO - Adding to queue: airflow run test_regex_1 dummy_2 2016-01-15T00:00:00 --local -s 2016-01-15T00:00:00 -sd DAGS_FOLDER/test_regex.py [2016-02-10 16:46:04,261] {base_executor.py:34} INFO - Adding to queue: airflow run test_regex_1 dummy_2 2016-01-15T01:00:00 --local -s 2016-01-15T00:00:00 -sd DAGS_FOLDER/test_regex.py [2016-02-10 16:46:09,242] {jobs.py:810} INFO - [backfill progress] waiting: 4 | succeeded: 2 | kicked_off: 4 | failed: 0 | wont_run: 0 [2016-02-10 16:46:09,244] {local_executor.py:29} INFO - LocalWorker running airflow run test_regex_1 dummy_2 2016-01-15T00:00:00 --local -s 2016-01-15T00:00:00 -sd DAGS_FOLDER/test_regex.py [2016-02-10 16:46:09,244] {local_executor.py:29} INFO - LocalWorker running airflow run test_regex_1 dummy_2 2016-01-15T01:00:00 --local -s 2016-01-15T00:00:00 -sd DAGS_FOLDER/test_regex.py [2016-02-10 16:46:09,756] {__init__.py:36} INFO - Using executor SequentialExecutor [2016-02-10 16:46:09,761] {__init__.py:36} INFO - Using executor SequentialExecutor Logging into: /Users/siddharth/Projects/airflow/logs/test_regex_1/dummy_2/2016-01-15T01:00:00 Logging into: /Users/siddharth/Projects/airflow/logs/test_regex_1/dummy_2/2016-01-15T00:00:00 [2016-02-10 16:46:10,727] {__init__.py:36} INFO - Using executor SequentialExecutor [2016-02-10 16:46:10,731] {__init__.py:36} INFO - Using executor SequentialExecutor [2016-02-10 16:46:14,246] {jobs.py:810} INFO - [backfill progress] waiting: 4 | succeeded: 2 | kicked_off: 4 | failed: 0 | wont_run: 0 [2016-02-10 16:46:14,255] {base_executor.py:34} INFO - Adding to queue: airflow run test_regex_1 bash_sqm_22 2016-01-15T01:00:00 --local -s 2016-01-15T00:00:00 -sd DAGS_FOLDER/test_regex.py [2016-02-10 16:46:14,266] {base_executor.py:34} INFO - Adding to queue: airflow run test_regex_1 bash_sqm_22 2016-01-15T00:00:00 --local -s 2016-01-15T00:00:00 -sd DAGS_FOLDER/test_regex.py [2016-02-10 16:46:19,250] {jobs.py:810} INFO - [backfill progress] waiting: 2 | succeeded: 4 | kicked_off: 6 | failed: 0 | wont_run: 0 [2016-02-10 16:46:19,251] {local_executor.py:29} INFO - LocalWorker running airflow run test_regex_1 bash_sqm_22 2016-01-15T01:00:00 --local -s 2016-01-15T00:00:00 -sd DAGS_FOLDER/test_regex.py [2016-02-10 16:46:19,251] {local_executor.py:29} INFO - LocalWorker running airflow run test_regex_1 bash_sqm_22 2016-01-15T00:00:00 --local -s 2016-01-15T00:00:00 -sd DAGS_FOLDER/test_regex.py [2016-02-10 16:46:19,755] {__init__.py:36} INFO - Using executor SequentialExecutor [2016-02-10 16:46:19,762] {__init__.py:36} INFO - Using executor SequentialExecutor Logging into: /Users/siddharth/Projects/airflow/logs/test_regex_1/bash_sqm_22/2016-01-15T00:00:00 Logging into: /Users/siddharth/Projects/airflow/logs/test_regex_1/bash_sqm_22/2016-01-15T01:00:00 [2016-02-10 16:46:20,723] {__init__.py:36} INFO - Using executor SequentialExecutor [2016-02-10 16:46:20,743] {__init__.py:36} INFO - Using executor SequentialExecutor [2016-02-10 16:46:24,252] {jobs.py:810} INFO - [backfill progress] waiting: 2 | succeeded: 4 | kicked_off: 6 | failed: 0 | wont_run: 0 [2016-02-10 16:46:29,257] {jobs.py:810} INFO - [backfill progress] waiting: 0 | succeeded: 6 | kicked_off: 6 | failed: 0 | wont_run: 0 [2016-02-10 16:46:29,264] {jobs.py:820} INFO - All done. Exiting. ```
Closing. If you feel this is not correct, ping me and I will reopen.
Closing for lack of activity
Not seeing this issue anymore. Closing

At Agari, we use airflow to spin up EMR clusters, execute steps, and spin down the cluster. We are hoping to generalize this as EMR operators. Otherwise, we use boto and the PythonOperator for everything on AWS (e.g. SQS, S3, SNS, etc...). Stay tuned for this coming functionality.

So, I use boto and AWS CLI on the same server where airflow runs. Assuming boto runs on this same box, airflow will default to using boto under the hood. If you use boto, then you may have a `~/.aws/credentials` file. That will work. Just remove an config from the `extra` field on the connection edit page.

Here's an example of a using an s3 key sensor : 
https://gist.github.com/r39132/b22671d0293cd7740b38

If you can encapsulate your logic in Python, you can simply use a PythonOperator. No need to master the array of different custom operators. Personally, I pretty much only use BashOperator and PythonOperator for everything. I leverage boto when I need to do anything AWS related.

For your case above, you can 
1. Use a BashOperator to execute the FTP
2. Use a BashOperator to unzip the downloaded file
3. Load the file into your MySQL library using the PythonOperator using your connector of choice
4. Send an email using the EmailOperator
Can you provide some more details here? I'm a little unclear on the problem and the symptom.
Reported and now being tracked in https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/issues/955. Closing this one as a duplicate.

Can you verify that your airflow home is set correctly in the ENV var? I suspect this is caused by 2 different set of migrations running from 2 different airflow installs. 

Also, is your issue resolved by a `airflow resetdb`? If you have a fresh install, `airflow resetdb` will likely resolve it. 

-s
@mistercrunch sure thing. Any ideas on how to make the logout link only show when we're logged in?

Working on this here:

https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/pull/987

sure.  Basically I had two tasks - lets call them A and B.   A is upstream of B.
A does some work, does an xcom_push (e.g. number_of_coins_flipped=6)
B performs and xcom_pull of this (e.g. notifies slack of number_of_coins_flipped).

I then cleared A (including downstream).  This time when A is run it fails - before the xcom_push,  B then runs (it wasn't set to check the state of A) and reports that 6 coins were flipped.

I appreciate that checking the state of A would also be a good idea, however it was unexpected behaviour and clearing the old xcom data seems reasonable (but maybe there are problems with that?)

One possible reason for that *might be in https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/blob/master/airflow/jobs.py#L373  where dag is being failed - but is that code ok? In my case there was no actual timeout

There should be at least some logging about the reason of failing the DAG stored in the 'DagRun' object to be viewed in the GUI. and of course in logs.

I think I can add more to this hypothesis.
Doing 'select \* from dag_run;' on this environment I can see all dag_runs' start_dates are the same - calculated when the dag file was first parsed.
This makes code for timeout verification notice timeout and the dag is failed...

Does this reasoning make sense?
Yes, we are going to export from bigquery to S3, we hope to be in production soon. It would be nice if there was an official release this week ;) otherwise we need to deploy the master branch.
Nice switcharoo. Thanks for the PR.
This is useful. Thanks for the PR.
I merged the fix, thanks for digging in.
Added a banner for errors and loading gif when it's fetching the data.
Added a glyph. Still displays when logged out, which is annoying. Could use pointers on how to fix that.
cc @bolkedebruin feedback welcome--just tweaking error messages to make fat-fingered usernames a bit more intelligible.
LGTM

I have your code running locally against sqllite and sequential executor. I modified `command` to print out the execution date (not the hour before the execution date): ``` def command(): return "echo {{ params.myparam }} {{ (execution_date).strftime('%Y/%m/%d %H %M') }} 2>&1 >> /tmp/logs_1" ``` The output looks normal. ``` sid-as-mbp:dags siddharth$ tail -f /tmp/logs_1 1 2016/02/11 11 58 1 2016/02/11 12 00 1 2016/02/11 12 03 2 2016/02/11 11 58 1 2016/02/11 12 06 2 2016/02/11 12 00 1 2016/02/11 12 09 2 2016/02/11 12 03 1 2016/02/11 12 12 2 2016/02/11 12 06 1 2016/02/11 12 15 2 2016/02/11 12 09 ```
@mistercrunch I think this is ready to be committed.
Closing for lack of info.

No need to raise coverage, we can't test Presto in travis (yet).

But we like lines under 80char to comply to PEP8.
I'm fine with having it show when people are logged off.
@r39132 @mistercrunch - any objections here?
My bad -- I have my editor set to 100 chars.  I'll revise...
This looks solid but pretty hard to test. I'm hoping I get some time to do a deep review.
Seems reasonable. I'm afraid when thinking about the worst case scenario. I can't think of any way to prevent from it.
This is great. Thanks for the feature!

@r39132 the webserver didn;t have any hiccup here, so we didn't try to mess with him. Furthermore the problem looks deeply inside scheduler, the logs from scheduler say the same.

and yes the dag_timeout is necessary to reproduce the issue - we removed this param on production and everything goes well since then.
![img](http://stream1.gifsoup.com/view3/2236736/stop-grammar-time-o.gif)

Hi @kretes,
Ok. So, can you confirm a few things for me, since I am unable to reproduce this issue. Are you getting the error because your tasks are taking longer than 4 minutes to run? I don't use celery and am wondering if the combined times of running and some necessary heart beating is exceeding the 4 minutes you have set as a timeout.

Something is wrong in the documentation:

From documentation:
class airflow.operators.TriggerDagRunOperator(dag_id, python_callable, _args, *_kwargs)
dag_id (str)  the dag_id to trigger

From test case:

```
        t = operators.TriggerDagRunOperator(
            task_id='test_trigger_dagrun',
            trigger_dag_id='example_bash_operator',
            python_callable=trigga,
            dag=self.dag)

```

Based upon further research it looks like there are two main sources of connection leaks. One is in the heartbeat method of the jobs module. That one is responsible for the huge number of idle in transaction connections. Calling settings.engine.dispose() in the heartbeat method seems to keep the number of these idle in transaction connections from growing unboundedly although 1000 active task instances still keeps about 300 DB connections busy at all times with the heartbeat. 

The other main source of leaks is in the TaskInstance class. Once I've dealt with the leak in jobs.py the number of "idle" connections begins to grown unboundedly until all connections run out and tasks start getting bounced. I've tried disposing the engine in a few key methods of that class but the session handling there is less straightforward and I haven't been able to figure it out yet.
@mistercrunch any feedback?
Rest seems fine and I am all good with better messages
What do you mean "positive" dn? With AD, what we see is a result with nothing but a search reference field.

Ah ok I get it. Patch seems fine then.

@mistercrunch

Has this been explored in a way where "state" could be set per dag? My dags run on machines in two colos (primary and secondary) as a result they (dags) are shared. In some cases a dag is written specifically for one colo. So I'd like to run this only for one but not the other. This feature would be useful in such cases.

@r39132 no the tasks are simple echos they complete in a few seconds including scheduling overhead.

I think the problem comes from the place in the code I pointed out. It would be good to add some better status for dag fail 'timeouted' instead of a general 'failed' to be sure, though.

When doing 'select \* from dag_run'
I see entries that have start date set to the moment I first 'deployed' this DAG. Therefore the dag run will be timeouted.

Did you try to reproduce the issue by cloning the repo I prepared and running docker-compose there?

I switched executor to 'local' and the same happens.
First a few dag runs go well but then they freeze (it first happens when dag run ends after a specified dag timeout added to a first start_date of first dag run. see the example when dag timeout was set to 1 minute:

![airflowdagruns](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1224887/13045254/9a01ebcc-d3d2-11e5-80f5-34445f8778b8.png)
I'm surprised I missed that while reviewing the previous PR...

That's probably more of a question to ask on the Celery/Cassandra side of things. We're open to enable the hooks and configurations you need to make this work though, send a PR with the hooks you need once you figure it out!

The current way to have dependencies on tasks from another DAG is to use the `ExternalTaskSensor` as documented here:
http://pythonhosted.org/airflow/code.html#airflow.operators.ExternalTaskSensor

We should raise an exception (or create an `ExternalTaskSensor` on your behalf!) when trying to reference a task from another DAG.
@aoen thoughts? Can we test that as soon as we get our staging cluster up and running?

100 nodes! nice to hear that. Ok well I've done some research on this before. SqlAlchemy pools connection, so even when adequately closing the connections in the code, sqla does some magic that you may or may not want. 

Here's how it's configured in the Airflow code:
https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/blob/master/airflow/settings.py#L58

More about sqla session pooling:
http://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/latest/core/pooling.html

It's probably safe to assume that it's nice for the web server and scheduler to have small connection pools, but that the individual `airflow run` commands should have none. Each heartbeat should pop a new connection and close it. I'm also ok with making those settings configurable.
I am also surprised I forgot to add it and not find it while reviewing myself :joy:

I agree about pooling on server vs. worker. Since workers scale out they should be extremely aggressive about letting go of DB connections. It looks like closing the session is not enough to close out the connections you actually need to dispose of the engine. I think I was able to pinpoint the culprit that was responsible for eating up connections ad infinitum. It was actually the TaskInstance class that was generating idle unclosed connections. Once I patched it, things got relatively under control. I will PR these changes some time this week. 

The heartbeat code still generates 1 idle_in_transaction connection per worker pretty much constantly. I was surprised to see this as I had switched the heartbeat to 60 seconds and dispose of the connections aggressively. I haven't had time to sort this out yet. It would be good to get this sorted as I want to be able to scale to about 6000 cores.

One thing that I noticed was that the session handling inside the airflow code isn't super consistent. Sometimes there is a centrally managed session and sometimes spurious sessions are created within methods. In general Sqlalchemy encourages session handling to be done centrally in a wrapper: http://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/latest/orm/session_basics.html#session-frequently-asked-questions
rather than in individual methods.
Closing for lack of activity. Please ping me (cc me) if you have more information.

I think I already implemented this for the HiveHook (ie. for the kerberos side of things).

There is however a big difference between running jobs as a separate user (ie. airflow changes its uid to another user) and doing the above. To do it properly you need something like privilege separation and authentication for the dags (ie signing them and then verifying them against a key that is known and authorized).

Of course you could just add (like I did in the HiveHook) the option to use a proxy user, but lets say I would have a very tough discussion with my security people if I would like to use this feature.

@mistercrunch sorry for the delay ... yes that's the issue ... it's the depend on past on the tasks within a subdag. There are some edge cases when I rerun a task instance in the past where I have marked the previous instances as success manually .. the task will not run. In fact it get's caught in a queued state and never gets picked up. Though other tasks progress through the queue just fine.

For us, service accounts are considered more secure.
E.g. let's comapre with airflow and ... sshd
- sshd:
  
  runs under root (real user id), and after user authenicates, uid locks down to an actual (effective user), so sshd child processes are running for that actual user. 
- Airflow:
  
  You have a service (airflow) that runs under one user ("airflow" is "real user id") and has ability to impersonate to other actual users after they are authenitcated by the service ("effective userid").

Given this example, I think it'll be easier to explain to the security people that this is actually more secure? I guess sshd might be a good reference point here.

``` shell
$ pstree -up | grep ssh
        |-sshd(2262)-+-sshd(2859)---sshd(2861,rdautkha)---ksh(2862)
        |            |-sshd(4967)---sshd(4973,rdautkha)---ksh(4974)-+-grep(5990)

$ ps -ef | egrep "2262|2859"
root      2262     1  0  2015 ?        00:00:11 /usr/sbin/sshd
root      2859  2262  0 Jan26 ?        00:00:00 sshd: rdautkha [priv]
rdautkha  2861  2859  0 Jan26 ?        00:00:00 sshd: rdautkha@pts/1

```

In our organization service accounts and authentication of end users by middle tier services/applications is considered a more secure practice. Thank you.

Hi @pedrorjbr, Great question and it's very confusing, I agree. This is screaming for better documentation. I put together an example to help you. There are some gotcha's however that tripped me up: 1. Make sure you run everything on UTC -- Airflow does not handle non-UTC dates in a clear way at all and in fact caused me scratch my head as I saw an 8 hour delay in my triggered dag_runs actually executing. 2. When you use the TriggerDagRunOperator, there are 2 DAGs being executed: the Controller and the Target. Both DAGs must be enabled. The Target DAG should have a `schedule_interval=None` **Illustrative Example:** **Step 1** : Define your Target DAG with `schedule_interval=None`. DAG_RUNs of this target will be created and executed every time that your trigger fires. ``` from airflow.operators import * from airflow.models import DAG from datetime import date, datetime, time, timedelta args = { 'start_date': datetime.now(), 'owner': 'airflow', } dag = DAG( dag_id='simple_dummy_dag_v1', default_args=args, schedule_interval=None) run_this = DummyOperator( task_id='run_this', dag=dag) ``` **Step 2** : Define your Controller DAG with any interval that makes sense for you! It's going to be checking a condition on that interval and triggering the Target DAG whenever the condition is met. In the example below, I am running it every minute and always executing the trigger. The idea of the `foo` function is to check a condition and then return dag_run_obj if you want to trigger the Target DAG. If your condition is not met, then return None. ``` from airflow import DAG, utils from airflow.operators import * from datetime import date, datetime, time, timedelta def foo(context, dag_run_obj): if True: return dag_run_obj dag = DAG(dag_id='test_trigger_dag_run_for_Sid', default_args={"owner" : "me", "start_date":datetime.now()}, schedule_interval='*/1 * * * *') trigger = TriggerDagRunOperator(task_id='test_trigger_dagrun', trigger_dag_id="simple_dummy_dag_v1", python_callable=foo, dag=dag ``` **Optional Step 3** : You can also manually trigger your Target DAG using the CLI, perhaps when testing or if you are using some custom automation via `trigger_dag simple_dummy_dag_v1` Your DAG_Run table will look like : You can see 3 types of entries (from top to bottom): - Manually triggered (via CLI) DAG_RUNs of the Target DAG (e.g. `run_id : manual__2016-02-15T22:57:49.996114`) - Controller triggered DAG_RUNs of the Target DAG (e.g. `run_id : trig__2016-02-15T22:26:37.425566`) - Controller DAG_RUNs (e.g. `run_id : scheduled__2016-02-15T11:15:00`) The documentation sucks. Please do your part and update it as and when questions are answered. I can do this one. Closing for now, but ping me here or on gitter if you need it reopened.
Are you running in UTC everywhere?

Hi @kretes, 
`[2016-02-08 15:55:25,118] {__init__.py:36} INFO - Using executor CeleryExecutor` is misleading. It's just printing out what the default executor is based on configuration when overrides (e.g. '-l') are not provided. In this case, the LocalExecutor will be used. The output should be changed. Would you like to submit a PR for it and I can merge it?

In terms of handling the return differently, feel free to submit a PR. There is one place where this is done: This looks correct, but it seems that cli.py is not bubbling this return code up! Instead, you are getting the return code of cli.py. In general, I'd say adding airflow to the path is the solution, but I agree this is something that could trip people up during setup. Hence, submit a PR and we will look at it.
I ran your code and reproduced it on the LocalExecutor. Interestingly, I was not able to reproduce it on the SequentialExecutor....

Exactly. Like I wrote the ideal way to go is privilege separation and have airflow set the effective uid. And yes ssh was what I had in mind. This is not trivial to implement though. 

> On 15 feb. 2016, at 22:54, Ruslan Dautkhanov notifications@github.com wrote:
> 
> For us, service accounts are considered more secure.
> E.g. let's comapre with airflow ... sshd
> 
> sshd:
> 
> runs under root (real user id), and after user authenicates, uid locks down to an actual (effective user), so sshd child processes are running for that actual user.
> 
> Airflow:
> 
> You have a service (airflow) that runs under one user ("airflow" is "real user id") and has ability to impersonate to other actual users after they are authenitcated by the service ("effective userid").
> 
> Given this example, I think it'll be easier to explain to the security people that this is actually more secure? I guess sshd might be a good reference point here.
> 
> $ pstree -up | grep ssh
>         |-sshd(2262)-+-sshd(2859)---sshd(2861,rdautkha)---ksh(2862)
>         |            |-sshd(4967)---sshd(4973,rdautkha)---ksh(4974)-+-grep(5990)
> 
> $ ps -ef | egrep "2262|2859"
> root      2262     1  0  2015 ?        00:00:11 /usr/sbin/sshd
> root      2859  2262  0 Jan26 ?        00:00:00 sshd: rdautkha [priv]
> rdautkha  2861  2859  0 Jan26 ?        00:00:00 sshd: rdautkha@pts/1
> In our organization service accounts and authentication of end users by middle tier services/applications is considered a more secure practice. Thank you.
>

Refer to the example I provide as the solution to the following issue : https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/issues/1001

You are missing the DAG definition, e.g. from my example on issue 1001.

```
dag = DAG(dag_id='test_trigger_dag_run_for_Sid',
          default_args={"owner" : "me",
                        "start_date":datetime.now()},
          schedule_interval='*/1 * * * *')
```
Closing issue. If you still have problems after reading my explanation on 1001, feel free to "@" ping me on gitter or here.
